FINAL CAST SELECTED

Evans Rodgers, President of the
Barnstormers Club, has been definitely chosen to play the lead in the
club's annual presentation, "The
Dictator," at the Lyric April first
and second. Other final decisions as
to the cast were announced this
week.
With two armies and a ship's
crew to assemble for the final production, Rodgers has issued a call
to the undergraduates for "extras."
All those wishing to portray soldiers
or sailors, on the Lyric stage are
urged to attend the rehearsal in the
Barn at ,3:30 P. M., Sunday, when
Coach Swindell will select those who
will appear in the final presentation.
Extra parts this year are of unusual
irnportance, many staying on the
stage through an entire act and entailing more ability than needed for
some of the F•peaking parts in the
actual cast
Cast Selected

Besides choice of Rodgers as
Brook Travers, the leading part in
the play, it was announced that
Richard Berney, a freshman, will
portray the principal female role.
The character of Jim, Travers' erstwhile valet, will be taken by "Benny" Boynton and Donald White will
play Hyne, a wireless operator. H.
Ridgley Warfield will play the comedy role of Duffy, a secret service
detective, Howard Caplan will be
Colonel Bowie, Consul to Porto
Banos, Jerome Natt Will enterpret
Captain Codman of the S. S. Bolivar, William P. White is cast as
Arthur Bostic, a missionary, and
Irving Gordon will grit his teeth in
the part of Campos, revolutionist
President.
The important character of Juanita, an impassioned Spanish senorita, has been assigned to Edward
Kreiling and the remaining female
part, Mrs. Bowie, will be taken care
of by I. Noyes Northup. Other
minor roles have been assigned to
Joseph Blandi, Robert McAll,
Charles Reese, Irvin Hoffman, Benjamin Kolb, and Walter Broening.

Four

Rehearsals Each Week

The Club is rehearsing four times
a week as the date of the final presentation gradually approaches,. and
as the scenery for the three acts
consists of but two sets, the production work is well under way. The
first set is on board the S. S. Bolivar and the last two acts take place
in the American consulate in
Porto Banos, a port of a Central American Republic. Unusual
scenic effects are being planned in
connection with the construction of
the scenery.
Just as last year a poster contest
was held at'the Maryland Institute
and the winning design, a striking
drawing by Miss Bertha Kelley, is
now being exhibited about the city.
Reserved seats for the performance were placed on sale at Albatigh's on March 8.

AMATEURISM
The other day we overheard a remark which had the unique
effect of making us think. "This Interfraternity Bridge Tournament," said one authority on the subject, "is a good thing. It
has the whole campus interested." A very natural remark, it
seemed at first, but one which illustrates an attitude which is so
prevalent that one sometimes wonders at it. The man did not
say that the players enjoyed it, or that the contest might pave
the way for more pleasant interfraternity relations, but only that
it was good because it interested the campus.
This spirit of showmanship, this desire to be a center of
attraction, is uppermost in nearly every undergraduate activity.
The Black and Blue Jay is more interested, and more successful,
in its advertising rates and its circulation increase, than in the
copy it turns out every month. We may be doing them an injustice, but we believe that most members of the Glee Club would
rather give a mediocre program to a full house than sing songs
they really enjoyed to a poor one, or to none at all. Not even
the debaters are free from this spirit; they would go to great
lengths to lure as many people as possible to their contests.
Activities certainly are for the enjoyment, and perhaps in
some degree for the training of those who take part in them.
A little serious self-examination might keep some of our activities from straying too far from their original path.

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
Contrary to the numerous denunciations issued against student participation in campus activities and athletics, based on the grounds that
such are harmful to the scholastic
ability of college students, it has
been computed by Dr. Earl J. Miller, dean of men at the University
of California, .in his recent statistical survey, that "students in activities made slightly better grades than
the students not engaged in activities." The investigation resulted,
when summarized, in the information that the 1954 male students
in the University made an average
grade of 1.21, while the group of
540 students participating in campus activities compiled an average
of 1.27. The averages of the nonparticipants was 1.16, or eleven
points lower than that established by
the former group.

Navy Riflemen
Down Jay Shooters
Meeting its second defeat in as
many weeks, the. Johns Hopkins Rifle Team fell before the Navy sharpshooters last Saturday in a close
match. The latter team -emerged
with only a ten-point lead, winning
by the score of 1390 to 1380.
Glantz accounted for the highest
individual score of the Hopkins
team with 281 as his total. The
members of the team with the four
next highest individual scores were
Reiblich shooting 279, Garis 275,
Baird 274., and Magness 271.
The highest score of any member of Navy's team was 282, but
these other representatives made
Scores nearly as high. The meet
was a shoulder-to-shoulder match,
Hopkins journeying to Annapolis
to encounter the Navy riflemen.

A new system of class elections
has been adopted at Lafayette College for the purpose of minimizing
campus politics. This new procedure contains two radical changes
from the means of election which
are now in general use. In the first
Place the elections are for five years
only, thus assuring the constant
interest of the officers in the class.
4t every fifth annual reunion the
class will choose new leaders. Secondly, the elections are of a preferential nature so that the best men
in the class, failing to be elected to
one office, are eligible to run for another. By this means it is believed
that the best men in the class will
be elected to fill the offices.

Evans Rodgers, President of the
Barnstormers Club, has been definitely chosen to play the lead in the
club's annual presentation, "The
Dictator," at the Lyric April first
and second. Other final decisions as
to the cast were announced this
week.
With two armies and a ship's
crew to assemble for the final production, Rodgers has issued a call
to the undergraduates for "extras."
All those wishing to portray soldiers
or sailors, on the Lyric stage are
urged to attend the rehearsal in the
Barn at ,3:30 P. M., Sunday, when
Coach Swindell will select those who
will appear in the final presentation.
Extra parts this year are of unusual
irnportance, many staying on the
stage through an entire act and entailing more ability than needed for
some of the F•peaking parts in the
actual cast
Cast Selected

Besides choice of Rodgers as
Brook Travers, the leading part in
the play, it was announced that
Richard Berney, a freshman, will
portray the principal female role.
The character of Jim, Travers' erstwhile valet, will be taken by "Benny" Boynton and Donald White will
play Hyne, a wireless operator. H.
Ridgley Warfield will play the comedy role of Duffy, a secret service
detective, Howard Caplan will be
Colonel Bowie, Consul to Porto
Banos, Jerome Natt Will enterpret
Captain Codman of the S. S. Bolivar, William P. White is cast as
Arthur Bostic, a missionary, and
Irving Gordon will grit his teeth in
the part of Campos, revolutionist
President.
The important character of Juanita, an impassioned Spanish senorita, has been assigned to Edward
Kreiling and the remaining female
part, Mrs. Bowie, will be taken care
of by I. Noyes Northup. Other
minor roles have been assigned to
Joseph Blandi, Robert McAll,
Charles Reese, Irvin Hoffman, Benjamin Kolb, and Walter Broening.

Four

Rehearsals Each Week

The Club is rehearsing four times
a week as the date of the final presentation gradually approaches,. and
as the scenery for the three acts
consists of but two sets, the production work is well under way. The
first set is on board the S. S. Bolivar and the last two acts take place
in the American consulate in
Porto Banos, a port of a Central American Republic. Unusual
scenic effects are being planned in
connection with the construction of
the scenery.
Just as last year a poster contest
was held at'the Maryland Institute
and the winning design, a striking
drawing by Miss Bertha Kelley, is
now being exhibited about the city.
Reserved seats for the performance were placed on sale at Albatigh's on March 8.

AMATEURISM
The other day we overheard a remark which had the unique
effect of making us think. "This Interfraternity Bridge Tournament," said one authority on the subject, "is a good thing. It
has the whole campus interested." A very natural remark, it
seemed at first, but one which illustrates an attitude which is so
prevalent that one sometimes wonders at it. The man did not
say that the players enjoyed it, or that the contest might pave
the way for more pleasant interfraternity relations, but only that
it was good because it interested the campus.
This spirit of showmanship, this desire to be a center of
attraction, is uppermost in nearly every undergraduate activity.
The Black and Blue Jay is more interested, and more successful,
in its advertising rates and its circulation increase, than in the
copy it turns out every month. We may be doing them an injustice, but we believe that most members of the Glee Club would
rather give a mediocre program to a full house than sing songs
they really enjoyed to a poor one, or to none at all. Not even
the debaters are free from this spirit; they would go to great
lengths to lure as many people as possible to their contests.
Activities certainly are for the enjoyment, and perhaps in
some degree for the training of those who take part in them.
A little serious self-examination might keep some of our activities from straying too far from their original path.

Contrary to the numerous denunciations issued against student participation in campus activities and athletics, based on the grounds that
such are harmful to the scholastic
ability of college students, it has
been computed by Dr. Earl J. Miller, dean of men at the University
of California, .in his recent statistical survey, that "students in activities made slightly better grades than
the students not engaged in activities." The investigation resulted,
when summarized, in the information that the 1954 male students
in the University made an average
grade of 1.21, while the group of
540 students participating in campus activities compiled an average
of 1.27. The averages of the nonparticipants was 1.16, or eleven
points lower than that established by
the former group.
